title: Vaccinations and Autism: Separating Fact from Fiction at Nao Medical
author: Dr Nao
description: Learn about the link between vaccinations and autism and how Nao Medical can help you make informed decisions about your health.
cleaned_text: There has been a lot of controversy surrounding the link between vaccinations and autism. Some people believe that vaccines can cause autism, while others argue that there is no scientific evidence to support this claim. At Nao Medical, we believe in providing our patients with accurate information so that they can make informed decisions about their health. The Facts About Vaccinations and Autism First and foremost, it is important to understand that there is no scientific evidence to support the claim that vaccinations cause autism. This myth originated from a 1998 study that has since been discredited and retracted by the medical journal that published it. Numerous studies have been conducted since then, and none have found a link between vaccinations and autism. It is also important to note that vaccines are rigorously tested and monitored for safety. Before a vaccine is approved for use, it undergoes extensive testing in clinical trials to ensure that it is safe and effective. Once a vaccine is on the market, it is continually monitored for any potential side effects. Why Vaccinations Are Important Vaccinations are an important tool in preventing the spread of infectious diseases. They work by stimulating the body's immune system to produce antibodies that can fight off specific diseases. When enough people in a community are vaccinated, it creates herd immunity, which means that even those who cannot receive vaccines due to medical reasons are protected from the disease. Some people argue that vaccines are not necessary because certain diseases, such as measles and polio, have been eradicated in the United States. However, these diseases still exist in other parts of the world, and unvaccinated individuals can still contract them when traveling abroad. Additionally, outbreaks of vaccine-preventable diseases can occur when vaccination rates drop below a certain threshold.
